awd_titl_txt: A workshop to discuss attrition of women in the academic ocean sciences leadership pipeline: Washington, D.C., 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
The Consortium on Ocean Leadership (COL) will host a workshop to focus on the issues surrounding the representation of women in tenure-track and tenured faculty positions in the ocean sciences. Given the percentage of women receiving doctorates in ocean sciences for the last two decades, the number of women in these faculty positions in the ocean sciences is lower than expected.  The workshop will invite representatives of academic institutions to review and discuss the available data on the representation of women at various levels in the ocean science doctorate-to-tenured-faculty pipeline, to consider the factors that influence women's experiences and decisions related to academic careers, and to determine if further investigation into these factors is needed. 

The workshop will be held at COL headquarters in Washington, DC with about twenty-two participants in late 2019. As a deliverable for this workshop, COL will provide an analysis of available data on the representation of women in the ocean sciences workforce, and results of the data analysis and recommendations from the workshop will be published in a major oceanographic journal. This workshop will support NSF goals of ensuring a diverse scientific workforce.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand the status (current and long-term trends) of the participation of women in academic ocean sciences and barriers to representation at all levels within university programs. To accomplish this, first we reviewed existing data on participation (doctoral, postdoctoral, and faculty) of women in academic ocean sciences. Much of this data comes from the Consortium for Ocean Leadership?s annual OSER surveys of graduate ocean science education programs, which was also compared with NSF?s Survey of Earned Doctorates (for the PhD recipient level). The data showed that, despite increases in the percentages of female doctorates, post-doctorates, and tenure-track and tenured faculty, academic ocean science was still far from having equal representation of women (<30%) at the tenured faculty level. The biggest loss of women appears to be at the post-doctoral scholar level. With the percentage of tenure-track faculty now more or less on par with the percentage of female postdoctoral scholars ? a typical piece of the academic trajectory ? the indication is that women will continue to remain underrepresented (~45%) in academic ocean science faculty for some time. It will require intentional efforts to address the apparent loss of women at the postdoctoral level and to take advantage of current growth in female tenure-track faculty, which appears to be intentional through new hires.

Next, we organized a [virtual] workshop in November 2020 to discuss the data, the factors presumed to influence women?s experiences and decisions to pursue and remain in academic careers, and recommendations for further investigation or action that may be needed to support the retention and progression of women in academic ocean science careers. There is no singular barrier to retaining women but compounding issues that must be addressed, including poor culture, gender bias, harassment, and work-life balance, as well as a lack of formal or creative mechanisms and resources for dual hires of academic couples, which has an outsized impact on women. There was concern, given the timing of the workshop, that the COVID-19 pandemic would further negatively impact women?s choices to stay in academia. The group recommended the OSER survey pay attention to unexpected changes in data trends

Since the workshop was held virtually (due to the pandemic), permission was granted to reallocate participant support costs to improving the annual OSER survey (for the 2020-2021 academic year and forward) based on recommendations from workshop participants. These improvements included:

  • Collecting ethnicity/race information by gender to improve understanding around intersectional identities.
  • Collecting ethnicity/race for the ocean science subdisciplines, which were previously correlated only to gender.
  • Clarifications to guide reporting of faculty in the various categories, aimed at ensuring greater reporting consistency between institutions.

We also conducted a special survey aimed at understanding COVID-19 related policies implemented during 2020-2021 that might inform interpretation of changes in trends or significant increases/decreases in percentages of women for this year. Most pandemic-related policies were lifted by the end of the 2020-2021 academic year, and we did not see anything alarming or unexpected in the that year?s data related to women or other underrepresented groups.
